translated: The Paṭṭhāna Treatise🔽The Dhamma Section in Pairs

analyzed: dhamma paccanīya duka paṭṭhāna pāḷi  rūpīduka

original: Narūpiṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca narūpī dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Narūpiṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca🔽naarūpī dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Narūpiṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca narūpī ca naarūpī ca

translated: With a form-and-formless condition, a formless state arises by way of root cause condition. With a formless condition,

original: dhammā uppajjanti hetupaccayā.🔽Naarūpiṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca naarūpī dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Naarūpiṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca

original: narūpī dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Naarūpiṁ dhammaṁ paṭicca narūpī ca naarūpī ca🔽dhammā uppajjanti hetupaccayā.🔽Narūpiñca naarūpiñca dhammaṁ paṭicca narūpī dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Narūpiñca
analyzed: narūpī dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā na arūpim dhammam paṭicca narūpī ca na arūpī ca  dhammā uppajjanti hetu paccayā  narūpiñca na arūpiñca dhammam paṭicca narūpī dhammaḥ uppajjati hetu paccayā narūpiñca
translated: a form-and-formless state arises by way of root cause condition. With a form-and-formless condition, a form-and-formless state arises by way of root cause condition.🔽With a form-and-formless condition, a formless state arises by way of root cause condition. With a form-and-formless condition,

original: naarūpiñca dhammaṁ paṭicca naarūpī dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Narūpiñca naarūpiñca
analyzed: na arūpiñca dhammam paṭicca na arūpī dhammo uppajjati hetu paccayā na rūpiñca na arūpiñca
translated: a formless state arises by way of root cause condition. With a form-and-formless condition, a formless state arises by way of root cause condition.

original: dhammaṁ paṭicca narūpī ca naarūpī ca dhammā uppajjanti hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)🔽Hetuyā nava, ārammaṇe tīṇi, adhipatiyā pañca …pe… aññamaññe cha …pe… purejāte āsevane ekaṁ …pe… avigate nava.
analyzed: dhammam paṭicca narūpī ca na arūpī ca dhammāḥ uppajjanti hetu paccayā  hetuyā nava ārammaṇe tīṇi adhipatiyā pañca pe aññamaññe cha pe purejāte āsevane ekam pe avigate nava
translated: and from a non-mental-fabrication-resultant and a mental-fabrication-resultant element, mental-fabrication-resultant and non-mental-fabrication-resultant dhammas arise. (In brief:)🔽Nine from a cause, three from an object, five from a predominance, … and so on as in §10 … six from a near connection, … one from a prenascence and from a postnascence, … one from nutriment, … one from association, … one from dissociation, … one from presence, … one from absence, … one from disappearance, … one from non-disappearance, … one from a root, … one from a condition.

analyzed: sahajāta vāre pi pe pañhā vāre pi sabbattha vitthāro
translated: (In the section on conascence, etc., and in the question section, all the triplets and couplets should be expanded in detail.)
